items.title: Search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 to resume

featured_image.name: HUGIN AUV to Ocean Infinity - Kongsberg Maritime

items.description:
The hunt for Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 will recommence on December 30, more than 11 years after the aircraft vanished with 239 people on board, Malaysian authorities announced this month, reigniting hopes that one of aviation's most enduring mysteries may finally be solved[1][2][3].

UK and US-based marine robotics company Ocean Infinity will lead the renewed effort, conducting a 55-day intermittent search of a targeted 15,000-square-kilometer area in the southern Indian Ocean[1][2][4]. The operation will deploy autonomous underwater vehicles capable of reaching depths exceeding 6,000 meters—technology unavailable during earlier search efforts[5][6].

The Boeing 777 disappeared from radar on March 8, 2014, during a routine flight from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing[1][2][4]. The aircraft carried 227 passengers, predominantly Chinese nationals, along with 12 Malaysian crew members[5][2][3]. Military radar later revealed the plane had deviated sharply from its flight path, turning back over northern Malaysia before heading into the Andaman Sea and then southward, after which all contact was lost[5][7][3].

items.title: Zelensky seeks 50-year US security guarantees

featured_image.name: Trump and Zelensky Meet to Iron Out Peace Plan, but Deal Remains Elusive

items.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Monday requested US security guarantees lasting up to 50 years, arguing that Ukraine needs longer-term commitments than the 15-year guarantee currently proposed in peace plan discussions with President Donald Trump.

Following their December 28 meeting at Mar-a-Lago, Zelensky told reporters that while draft documents include "strong" US security guarantees for 15 years with the possibility of extension, he pressed Trump to consider a significantly longer timeframe[1][2][3][4]. "I told him that we are already at war and it has been going on for almost 15 years," Zelensky said in a WhatsApp message to journalists, referencing the conflict that began with Russia's 2014 annexation of Crimea and support for separatists in eastern Ukraine[4][5][6]. "I told him that we would really like to consider the possibility of 30, 40, 50 years," he added[1][7][6].

Trump responded that he would "think about" the proposal, according to Zelensky[8][7][9]. The president offered no immediate commitment, though both leaders described the two-hour meeting as productive and suggested progress toward ending the nearly four-year full-scale war.

items.title: Russia claims Ukraine attacked Putin's residence with 91 drones

featured_image.name: Russia says Ukraine tried to attack Putin's residence so Moscow's negotiating stance will change

items.description:
Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov announced Monday that Ukraine attempted to strike President Vladimir Putin's residence in the Novgorod region with 91 drones, vowing the attack would prompt Moscow to toughen its position in ongoing peace negotiations.

The alleged assault occurred overnight between December 28 and 29, according to Lavrov, who told Russian state news agencies TASS and Interfax that all drones were destroyed by air defenses[1][2][3]. "Such recklessness will not go unanswered," Lavrov said, though he did not specify whether Putin was present at the residence during the incident[1]. Ukraine has not responded to the claims.

The announcement comes one day after U.S. President Donald Trump hosted Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at Mar-a-Lago, where both leaders expressed cautious optimism about reaching a peace deal to end the nearly four-year war. Trump said the parties were "getting a lot closer, maybe very close" to an agreement, while Zelenskyy reported that a 20-point peace plan was "90 percent agreed upon"[4][5].

items.title: SoftBank nears deal to acquire DigitalBridge data center firm

featured_image.name: SoftBank in Talks to Buy Data-Center Investor DigitalBridge

items.description:
SoftBank Group Corp. is in advanced discussions to acquire DigitalBridge Group Inc., a move that would significantly expand the Japanese conglomerate's footprint in artificial intelligence infrastructure as demand for data centers surges globally. The deal could be announced as early as Monday, according to Bloomberg News[1][2][3][4].

The potential acquisition would give SoftBank control over approximately $108 billion in digital infrastructure assets, including data centers, cell towers, and fiber networks[2][5][6]. Financial terms of the transaction have not been disclosed, and while talks are at an advanced stage, a final agreement has not yet been reached[1][2][3].

items.title: Global stocks close 2025 at record highs

featured_image.name: Stock market today: Dow, S&P 500 notch records, Nasdaq gains as Wall Street flies high into Christmas holiday

items.description:
World equities were on track to end 2025 at record highs on Monday, capping an extraordinary year for markets as investors bet on further Federal Reserve interest rate cuts and strong artificial intelligence-fueled gains across Asia[1][2].

The MSCI world equity gauge notched an almost 21% year-to-date gain after Wall Street hit a record high on Friday and European shares touched an intraday record high in early Monday trading[1][2]. The S&P 500 closed at 6,932.05 on Christmas Eve, marking its 39th record close of 2025[3][4].

items.title: China to hold live-fire drills around Taiwan Tuesday

featured_image.name: Taiwan holds live-fire drill during war games as tensions rise

items.description:
China's military will conduct live-fire exercises around Taiwan on Tuesday, surrounding the self-governing island with drills spanning five designated zones in a show of force that underscores Beijing's escalating military pressure in the region.

The People's Liberation Army Eastern Theater Command announced Sunday that the exercises will take place from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. on December 30, warning all vessels and aircraft to avoid the designated areas[1][2][3]. State news agency Xinhua reported the drills, named "Just Mission 2025," will focus on naval and air force combat readiness and securing strategic ports[4][5].

The announcement comes just days after China imposed sanctions on 20 U.S. defense companies and 10 executives on December 26, retaliating against Washington's approval of an $11.1 billion arms package to Taiwan—the largest ever U.S. weapons deal with the island[6][7][8]. The sanctions targeted major contractors including Northrop Grumman, Boeing, and L3Harris, freezing their assets in China and barring dealings with them[7][8].

items.title: Trump, Zelenskyy say Ukraine peace plan is 90% complete

featured_image.name: Trump welcomes Zelenskyy for talks, asserts Russia and ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy held high-stakes talks at Mar-a-Lago on Sunday, discussing a revised peace framework to end Russia's nearly four-year war in Ukraine, with Trump expressing optimism about reaching a deal despite unresolved territorial disputes.

The meeting came hours after Trump held a phone call with Russian President Vladimir Putin, a move that caught Ukrainian officials off guard[1][2][3]. Trump described the hour-long conversation as "good and very productive" and said he would call Putin again after concluding his discussions with Zelenskyy[4][5].

items.title: Putin, Trump reject temporary Ukraine ceasefire, Kremlin Says

featured_image.name: Trump, Putin agree to seek limited ceasefire in step to ...

items.description:
The Kremlin announced Sunday that Russian President Vladimir Putin and U.S. President Donald Trump jointly oppose a European-Ukrainian proposal for a temporary ceasefire, with Moscow insisting Ukraine must cede control of the Donbas region before any peace agreement can be reached.

Kremlin foreign policy aide Yuri Ushakov revealed that Putin and Trump spoke for one hour and 15 minutes at Trump's request, hours before the U.S. president's scheduled meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at Mar-a-Lago in Florida[1][2][3]. According to Ushakov, both leaders agreed that "the option of a temporary ceasefire proposed by the Ukrainians and the Europeans under the pretext of preparing for a referendum or under other pretexts only leads to a prolongation of the conflict and is fraught with renewed hostilities"[1][2].

items.title: Iranian president says Tehran at war with US, Israel, and Europe

featured_image.name: Iran president says US, Israel, Europe waging ‘full-fledged war’ on country

items.description:
Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian declared on December 27 that his country is in a "full-fledged war" with the United States, Israel, and Europe[1][2][3], marking a dangerous escalation as Tehran rapidly rebuilds its nuclear capabilities following devastating military strikes and abandons all international constraints on its atomic program.

The stark warning comes as Iran possesses 441 kilograms of uranium enriched to 60% purity as of June 2025, according to International Atomic Energy Agency reports[4][5][6]—alarmingly close to the 90% weapons-grade threshold needed for nuclear weapons. Western intelligence agencies warn that Iran has assembled all necessary components for weaponization and could complete the process quickly if ordered[7][8].

items.title: Harvard physicist disputes NASA on interstellar comet

featured_image.name: NASA releases close-up pictures of interstellar comet 3I/Atlas - PBS

items.description:
As the interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS recedes from its closest approach to Earth last week, a contentious scientific debate has intensified over whether the mysterious visitor from beyond our solar system could be artificial technology rather than a natural object. Harvard physicist Avi Loeb continues to argue that unusual features of the comet warrant consideration of extraterrestrial origins, while NASA and mainstream astronomers maintain overwhelming evidence points to natural cometary behavior.

On December 18, the Breakthrough Listen program conducted a technosignature search of 3I/ATLAS using the 100-meter Green Bank Telescope, less than 24 hours before the object's closest approach to Earth[1][2]. The search, which scanned radio frequencies from 1 to 12 gigahertz, found no artificial signals down to a sensitivity of 100 milliwatts[2]. "We report a nondetection of candidate signals down to the 100 mW level," researchers wrote in findings published this week[2].

The comet passed within approximately 168 million miles of Earth on December 19, posing no threat to our planet[3][4]. Discovered on July 1 by the NASA-funded ATLAS telescope in Chile, 3I/ATLAS is only the third confirmed interstellar object ever detected passing through our solar system, following 1I/'Oumuamua in 2017 and 2I/Borisov in 2019[3][5].

items.title: Zelenskyy to present updated 20-point peace plan in meeting with Trump

featured_image.name: As Trump and Zelenskyy meet in Florida, Kyiv hopes this time will be different

items.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy arrived in Florida on Sunday to meet with President Donald Trump at Mar-a-Lago, presenting a revised 20-point peace proposal aimed at ending nearly four years of war with Russia[1][2][3][4][5]. The meeting, scheduled for 1 p.m. local time, comes one day after Russia unleashed a massive attack on Kyiv using approximately 500 drones and 40 missiles, killing at least two people and leaving a third of the capital without heating[1][6][7][8][9].

Zelenskyy described the plan as "about 90% ready," signaling what both Ukrainian and U.S. officials characterized as substantial progress in negotiations[4][5][10][11]. The proposal includes NATO-style security guarantees modeled on Article 5, provisions for demilitarized zones in eastern Ukraine, and arrangements for disputed territories[12][13][14][15]. However, Trump emphasized his final authority over any agreement, telling Politico on Friday: "He doesn't have anything until I approve it. So we'll see what he's got"[16][4][5].

items.title: Thwaites Glacier retreating faster than expected, study warns

featured_image.name: Scientists weigh giant sea curtain to shield 'Doomsday Glacier' from ...

items.description:
Antarctica's Thwaites Glacier is retreating faster than anticipated, with new research revealing fractures and underwater erosion that threaten to destabilize the massive ice sheet and trigger catastrophic sea-level rise affecting hundreds of millions of coastal residents worldwide.

Scientists from the International Thwaites Glacier Collaboration released findings in their 2025 report showing the glacier's retreat "has accelerated considerably over the past 40 years"[1]. While a full collapse is unlikely to occur in the next few decades, the glacier "is set to retreat further, and faster, through the 21st and 22nd centuries," potentially leading to a general collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet by the 23rd century[1][2].
